text: I was under the impression that I was catching exceptions, the block that is blowing up is inside a try{}catch(Exception e){} block
well? it crashed anyway :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
it’s a native crash
a native crash? theres no native code in my app :disappointed:
it's in the runtime
that means you put too much data into an intent
intent/bundle
You’re sending too much data
some call's return value/arguemnts are too large
ah, <@U055GGAHS> was fasta
Android itself does native things. What they say ^
ok, so what in that error means that I sent too much data? it seems pretty obscure to me
TransactionTooLargeException
it just cant tell you exactly where because it happens on a message queue
<@U0DTEGLJF>, no. Initially the video is shown with other information below it
it's actually pretty well documented: <https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/TransactionTooLargeException.html>
<@U0A0S0WG0>: do you send some `Intent` (`startActivity()`, `sendBroadcast()`, `startService()`, etc)?
or `Bundle`
its `notifyObservers(Bundle data);`
so yeah
yep
so — don’t put a lot of data in it
hard hard hard rule.. only ever put meta data in bundles
limit is near to 1 mb, as far as I remember
thats why setData takes a Uri
so
i’m only sending a single string and int
and it doesn’t have very useful collection methods.. they didnt want people abusing it as its pretty heavy to move that data cross process
look at facebook code, they might have a hack to extend it to 1GB so it can handle their scale

json as a string is a common cause for the exception
its not json
format does not matter, just make sure that it can not be big

depending on what you are requesting
theres a stackoverflow error right above it

>If you are implementing a service, it may help to impose size or complexity contraints on the queries that clients can perform. For example, if the result set could become large, then don't allow the client to request more than a few records at a time. Alternately, instead of returning all of the available data all at once, return the essential information first and make the client ask for additional information later as needed.

hmm... so if I bind views with kotterknife using lazy delegates in a fragment, they hold reference to the stale views if the fragment's view is destroyed and recreated. not sure if that's expected, it just caused me like 1+ hour debugging around my FragmentPagerAdapter :confused:
<@U0546QERR>: well, it looks obvious… If you haven’t nulled them manually, why references would be cleared?
i guess it wouldn't happen in java because you inject the views deliberately in onCreateView
// ~~inject~~ -> `bind`
<@U0546QERR>: no difference in Java, until root object with references will be referenced by someone — all child references will be alive too
I guess, with `ButterKnife` you just used `unbind()`
yeah there's nothing like that in kotterknife i don't think. the examples just have you do `by bindView(R.id.foo)`
maybe there should be
i remember this weirding me out when i started using it but i got comfortable with it working and couldn't figure it out for a while today :x
Two solutions: `null` references in `onDestroyView()` or just remove references to the `Fragment` itself
if i unbind the references manually i think i should just stop using the library entirely, it's only useful because it gets rid of that boilerplate
What do you think about……… running RxJava tests on Android! <https://github.com/ReactiveX/RxJava/pull/3519>

attachments.title: Run tests on Android! by artem-zinnatullin · Pull Request #3519 · ReactiveX/RxJava · GitHub
attachments.text: Closes #3503. In short: Created rxjava gradle module and moved src to rxjava/src. Created android-tests module and configured it to run tests from rxjava/src/test on Android. Tuned build scripts...
